Award.AwardTitle: A Longitudinal Study of the Dimensions of Disciplinary Culture to Enhance Innovation and Retention among Engineering Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant studies differences in disciplinary culture between undergraduates in engineering and in other disciplines to better understand the relationship between disciplinary cultural identity and academic outcomes of engineering students. The goal of the study is to identify aspects of disciplinary culture that are major factors in addressing issues that a critical for engineering education in the future, such as innovation, creativity, and diversity. The grant applies Hofstede?s dimensions of culture (power distance, collectivism/individualism, femininity/masculinity, and uncertainty avoidance) to explain how students develop skills to operate within a discipline and across disciplines. Furthermore, the grant explores the relationship between disciplinary culture and student recruitment and retention in engineering programs, particularly with respect to underrepresented groups. The investigators? prior work with interdisciplinary design teams indicates that the dimension of uncertainty avoidance is especially critical: the ability to tolerate and even embrace uncertainty supports innovative interdisciplinary design practice. In addition, while many engineering students may be less likely to tolerate uncertainty, those engineers who do embrace uncertainty may find themselves alienated from engineering curricula. This pattern, in turn, may impact diversity in engineering student populations.

Consequently, the grant addresses five research questions: 1) How do Hofstede?s dimensions of culture map to academic disciplines? 2) What are the relationships between the dimensions of culture and (a) student choice of major and (b) student success with a major? 3) How do students change over time in their academic programs with respect to the dimensions of culture? 4) What factors affect those changes, e.g., curriculum, instructors? 5) Do the relationships in above show any variation by demographic indicators, e.g., race or gender? To investigate these questions, the grant includes a multi-university study that examines the dimensions of culture across the university, and then follows the development of students within engineering. The intellectual merit of the grant includes developing an actionable theory of disciplinary culture that can support pedagogies of inclusive and collaborative innovation. Despite widespread agreement that engineers for the 21st century must be more creative and innovative, there has been little progress in developing engineering pedagogies that support those goals. The results of the grant can be used by engineering programs to better design curricula that support innovation and creativity. The broader impacts include having a better understanding of the role of disciplinary culture in recruiting and retaining students, particularly with respect to groups that are currently underrepresented in engineering. This grant informs the debate about the role of engineering design in training U.S. engineers to meet the technical challenges of the 21st century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contemporary engineers work in global environments with colleagues from a range of fields well beyond engineering – business, architecture and design, sociology, policy and governance, and more. At the same time, engineering fields continue to struggle to recruit a diverse workforce to better support global innovation. As a result, there is increasing interest in both preparing engineers to be effective in cross-cultural, cross-disciplinary contexts and expanding the diversity of the profession. Toward that end, this project used Hofstede’s dimensions of national culture (power distance, collectivism/individualism, femininity/masculinity, and uncertainty avoidance) to explore how students experience their disciplinary education and what cultural norms they adopt or value. We selected Hofstede’s work because it was developed for international business environments, making it potentially useful in characterizing workplace collaborations across disciplines, understanding how student preferences with respect to those dimensions affect their experiences in school, and identifying ways to enhance curricula to better support a diverse global workforce.

The project collected three types of data: (1) a cultural dimensions survey across multiple degree programs and academic years at Virginia Tech, (2) cultural dimensions surveys of students in two degree programs (electrical and computer engineering, and industrial and systems engineering) at Virginia Tech and six other institutions across the U.S.,  and (3) interviews with students and site coordinators at all seven institutions.

The survey data indicated that the most significant difference across disciplines was in the dimension of uncertainty avoidance, with limited differences in the other dimensions of Hofstede’s model. Uncertainty avoidance reflects the degree to which individuals seek to both avoid ambiguity and minimize risk; engineering disciplines showed higher uncertainty avoidance than other disciplines, but the results also varied by discipline. While uncertainty avoidance can be a positive quality in creating structures, systems, and devices that are safe, it can limit innovation and exploration.

To understand these cultural dimensions in the context of students’ perceptions of and experiences with teaching and learning across disciplines and across institutions, the research team analyzed the interviews with students and site coordinators. The findings yielded a more complex picture in which both disciplinary and local departmental/institutional cultures differed in three areas: perceptions of teaching and learning, perceptions of course environment, and perceptions of disciplinary values. While some national and disciplinary trends emerged, the findings emphasized the importance and power of local departmental cultures in fostering increased acceptance of ambiguity and willingness to engage in collaborative work, both of which can support a more creative and innovative workforce. The results have significant implications for engineering programs seeking to design curricula that better support innovation and creativity and engage a diverse workforce. The key intellectual merit and the broader impacts of this project are as follows:

1) Findings point to a more nuanced model of teaching and learning across disciplines than prior studies that includes not only how teaching happens (e.g. lecture versus active learning) but also what disciplines value and reward. Thus curriculum designers and faculty developers must move beyond what teachers do to consider how disciplinary values are conveyed.

2) The two engineering disciplines studied (electrical and computer engineering, and industrial and systems engineering) showed marked differences in attitudes toward both collaboration and uncertainty. The emergence of these differences helps research move beyond treating engineering as a monolithic field with a single teaching and learning culture, and points to ways engineering subfields may be able to learn from one another strategically to promote positive change.

3) Uncertainty avoidance, including both ambiguity intolerance and risk avoidance, is a primary differentiator across majors and academic years, and appears to be closely linked to differences in teaching and learning practices. By linking classroom practices to characteristics associated with innovation, these results can help educators identify and select specific practices to better prepare engineering students for collaborative global innovation.

4) Our cross-institutional analysis revealed variations in student perceptions that suggest ways in which local cultures—departmental and institutional—may influence approaches to learning and perceptions of teaching practices locally, indicating that local cultures may override traditional characterizations of engineering disciplines. These findings in part point to substantial changes in culture at some institutions resulting from the past decade of research in engineering education. At the same time, they foreground the significance of such changes at departmental and institutional levels in impacting students’ experiences of disciplinary practices and values, and they challenge the idea of engineering culture as monolithic and immovable.
